Award.AwardTitle: Fluids in Continental Fault Zones: Evidence From Neomineralized Clays
Award.AbstractNarration:
Newly-grown clays in fault rock preserve the isotopic signature of fluids that were present during faulting, and will be used to constrain the plumbing of shallow fault systems and the dominant source of fluids. Examining fluid infiltration and circulation of crustal fault systems tests the hypothesis that fluids originating at the surface are the dominant phase in strike-slip fault and normal fault systems. This research project will use paired oxygen and hydrogen isotopic measurements on newly-grown illite from a suite of detachment (normal) fault systems in southwestern United States and continental strike-slip faults (San Andreas Fault, Alpine Fault, North Anatolian Fault). These faults contain neomineralized clays and are well-studied examples of major continental fault systems. The field approach utilizes surface sampling and recent drill core, while the laboratory works involves stable and radiogenic analyses, supported by various sample characterization studies.

Studying fluid circulation in natural fault systems is fundamental to understanding the role of fluids within the upper crust, which has major implications for the strength and seismogenesis of faults, and the formation of economic deposits. The approach in this study can be applied to many fault systems around the world to examine the relative contributions of metamorphic (deep) and meteoric (surface) fluids, so it has excellent potential for broad application. This field and laboratory project includes graduate and undergraduate students at the University of Michigan, and involves international collaboration with several field and laboratory experts. The training of young scientists contributes significantly to tomorrow's needs for human capital in science, math and engineering fields. Results will be published in the professional literature and inserted in appropriate public outreach and teaching setting, as well as scientific presentations by team members.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Determining the sources and pathways of geofluids in deforming crust is key to understanding the alteration of rocks, the strength of (seismogenic) faults, the formation of economic deposits, and other fluid-mediated geologic processes. Neomineralized clay phases, particularly illite and smectite, preserve the isotopic signature of geofluids that were present during deformation, constraining the dominant source of these fluids and the plumbing of fault systems in the upper crust. This study focused on fluid infiltration and circulation in shallow crustal fault systems. We developed of a robust methods to constrain fluid signatures and timing from H- and Ar-isotopic analysis of clay grain-size fractions, and used specific geologic settings to test the hypothesis that meteoric fluids are a dominant phase in many shallow fault systems. The target areas for this study were detachment faults in the SW US, contractional structures in central Mexico, and continental strike­slip settings in New Zealand (Alpine Fault) and Turkey (North Anatolian Fault).  Results from these studies show that surface-derived (=meteoric) fluids are much more important than previously assumed; in places, it is the primary source of geofluid (see figure).  Surface-derived fluids require significant downward fluid infiltration into deforming upper crust, likely along evolving faults and fractures, which connect with deeper fault zones that were previously found to contain similar meteoric fluid signatures.  The record of infiltrating fluids is preserved in newly-formed clays that range from thin smears in fracture zones to thick gouge layers in major fault zones. Our approach to constrain the relative contributions of basinal, metamorphic and meteoric fluids in evolving natural systems can be applied to most shallow fault systems around the world.

In addition to these field-oriented studies, we developed an in-situ method to study clay hydration state, we systematically catalogued clay transformations in natural fault rocks and incorporated one of the first applications of slice­-and-­view (FIB-SEM) electron microscopy on friable clay-rich rocks.
